So that's the underlying Group philosophy, that is to have a base, a foundation including in emerging countries that makes for a firm footing, visibility, sustainability, but at the same time we want to set aside a little bit of flexibility, keep some freedom for maneuver, so that we can move on market opportunities as they arise.
Is there a future question?

My name is . Two questions, just to confirm I've understood in this supply for gas your message for 2011 is clear, EBITDA down, but will remain positive, so the range is wide between zero and €500 million EBITDA 2012 when you start crafting scenarios. You mentioned 100 terawatt hours open assuming the – an assumption of five and six terawatt hours of negative spread. So we'll have an EBITDA, all other things being equal, at best at zero and at worst at €1.5 billion negative. Is my reading right?

And mid term last year you released for 2011 on ranges for the full Global Gas division E&P growing contribution because of values for midstream, are you perhaps prepared to discuss your average contributions on a cycle or a normalized spread for the mid term?

So that's the first part of my questions, and then a big leap to Asia now for my second question, which – through all your presentations and those of your peers, which is a promising growth market, no doubt the company, the best established amongst your European peers in Asia. Could you connect the dots between your various assets; the assets on your affiliates, International Power SUEZ Environment projects and liquefaction? What are the areas essentially the business segment, secondly the geographies, that you view as most promising towards which you plan to shift your CapEx? Five years down the road when you speak of the EDFSUEZ in a – GDF SUEZ in Asia, I mean how would you describe your presence and perhaps quantify it in EBITDA terms?
Well, I'm going to turn to Jean-François for the first part of your question on gas.

Well, there might have been a slight miss – what you said was right on 2011, zero, €600 million, don't challenge that. That's the range on supply in total EBITDA 2011 up over the two – that's 800 EP last year, but 1,350 EBITDA, so that's a conceptually as it were to compensate what would be lesser revenues in supply in 2011 versus 2010 for the next year. 100 terawatt hours, the spread is around €600 million that you mentioned, but you mustn't remove them from the zero base this year. Well, we're reopening as it were, we revert to €600 million and then we see what we can do to bring that down. So you mustn't have two increments down.

We come back to a situation that's €600 million and then we see what we can gain. So 2012 without wishing to go too far here might – it might, I mean, this is a very long way ahead. It could be of the same order as 2011. But not negative today. We can't conceive of a situation in which the supply activities would lose money. Make less but not lose money. Have to be a spread that opens up hugely that there is no possibility for renegotiation, factors that today are not on the agenda, so it's rather difficult to provide, to predict normalized spreads. There in lies the difficulty in supply given trading, arbitrage, optimization, varying international and varying gas prices between region, very difficult to give a precise prediction of the out years for gas price.

In spite of your wishes, I think you'll have to remain in some uncertainties that doesn't please us, as long as you don't call it the black box. I mean if you call it the black box, it's more bothersome. But we see what we can do and we've given some quite specific color on the ranges, on the limits of the exercise. But once again bear in mind for 2011 that there should be a moderate growth.
We're running short of time, so I'll answer your question and it will be the last for this session unfortunately.

Phil Cox, if he wishes might give some color to the few words I said in introduction. I'll say in introduction. For us, the emerging market, the emerging world is not just Asia. It's Latin America, which today accounts for more than Asia in our balance, in our capital employed. It's also the Middle East that accounts for less. And Asia – in Asia, we are – we've been present for a long time in Asia, but always very selectively for over 20 years in water, in China through SUEZ Environment, but we don't – we still don't wish to be there in the field of power generation, because we don't have enough visibility on the system of regulation.

However, in other parts of Asia, be it in Thailand, where we're the leading private producer, be it Singapore, where with our partners, we're the leading power producer with positions that International Power brings to the Group, very strong, bolstering us in Thailand, providing us with positions in Indonesia. That's very, very strong in a country that is hugely powerful. It's the number one country behind the BRIC in terms of growth and GDP.

So we really want to look closely at these countries. Also Australia is a country in which SUEZ Environment is very present. I mentioned that earlier where International Power is very present and through power generation, where we weren't present with a leading position, we wish to expand also in LNG.

We've acquired with the Santos partner reserves in Northwestern Australia offshore, and we're looking at a possibility of having those exploited by large offshore liquefaction platform to service the Asia market. I indicated that we've signed two keynote contracts for supplying LNG to South Korea and to China, so there is a shift in the center of gravity towards Asia-Pacific in some of our activities. Notably, the international gas and LNG business, but it's too soon at this stage to quantify those changes. We have a historic presence that will allow us to be very selective. We don't want to be present everywhere in all our business.
I don't know, Phil, if you want to give or not some additional explanations.
Okay. I kind of said it all, I covered everything. Great. Well, thanks, ladies and gentlemen. Have a nice day.
